results.title: Skyfall
results.creator_credit: Robby Susanto, Lu Gao and Animation and Interactive Media (AIM) RMIT
results.brief_description:
Great collaboration between a 2D and 3D animator to create a composite of cutout animation styles. A series of landscapes are degraded by human activities, in a dreamlike meditation on the despoilment of nature.
Graduate work from an AIM (Centre for Animation and Interactive Media) RMIT graduate, 2006.

group_siblings.title: Little Claude - a'hunting he will go

results.title: Little Claude - a'hunting he will go
results.brief_description: The Straford Brothers’ first attempt at a hand drawn animation. Frank recalls that it was done by drawing on a single cell, filming it, then rubbing it out and drawing the next frame on top, “a pretty laborious way to make an animation.”
results.description: The Straford Brothers’ first attempt at a hand drawn animation. Frank recalls that it was done by drawing on a single cell, filming it, then rubbing it out and drawing the next frame on top, “a pretty laborious way to make an animation.”

results.title: Workman's nightmare
results.brief_description:
An early experiment filmed in the Straford backyard in Brighton. It features the acting debut of 14 year-old John - as a workman who tussles with an unruly ladder.
This short work from 1951 marked the boys earliest efforts.

results.title: Hoop culture
results.brief_description: Created in response to a class assignment to offer a visual interpretation of ‘cultural identity’, this short After Effects animation focuses itself on different aspects of the ‘hoop culture’ of amateur basketball around melbourne.

results.title: The Pier
results.brief_description: Short film shot 1990 on Super 8 Film of St Kilda Pier (burnt down 2003). Filmed early in the morning, the moody feel of the work is heightened by atmospheric soundtrack (added by ACMI) Captures the shared experience of a morning spent at this popular spot for St Kilda residents.

results.title: Phantom
results.brief_description: This video work is a mysterious, ghostly geography of cinematic shadows. Silhouettes that never quite take shape shift and glide across the screen, anaemic figures, seen in the negative, forced to wander between narratives restlessly but caught in a loop. These remnants from faint memories of filmic melodrama are a living dead confined to a space they cannot leave. They are the secret that lies between stories.
